Monsieur H. Kloussè est né à Togoville (Préfecture de Vo) le 04 avril 1966. Du fait de l’état de pauvreté avancé de ses parents, il a été très vite éjecté du système scolaire et mis en apprentissage. Le soutien de ses parents au cours de sa formation de menuiserie ne dura que six (06) mois. Courageux et entreprenant, il s’est pris en charge lui-même grâce aux travaux domestiques qu’il exerçait en dehors des heures de formation. Il termina avec succès son apprentissage mais mit assez de temps pour ouvrir un atelier, faute de moyens. Le modeste atelier qu’il tient aujourd’hui grâce à un premier crédit de $350 n’est pas bien équipé, ce qui explique les nombreux retards dans les livraisons à ses clients qui ont du mal à le quitter à cause de la qualité de ses meubles. Marié sans enfant avec une couturière qui, elle aussi, éprouve d’énormes difficultés financières pour s’installer, Monsieur H. Kloussè essaie de tout faire pour ne pas exposer sa pauvreté. Il sait bien gérer son atelier et son foyer Le crédit de $850 que sollicite Kloussè va servir à acquérir une petite machine pour sa menuiserie et à faire un stock de bois pour sa revente car il en manque sérieusement dans le quartier. Ce projet lui permettra d’augmenter ses revenus pour mieux s’occuper de sa femme et ses deux nièces à leur charge.

loans.use: to acquire a little machine and build up a wood stock for sale

loans.name: Massawonda

texts.en:
Born in Ghana in 1970, Ms. Massawonda M. is a rice retailer in Tabligbo, Yoto prefecture. A mother of 4, she also cares for 3 other people. Abandoned by her husband, her current business does not allow her to meet the financial needs of her family. In order to develop a side business to supplement the sale of rice, she is in need of financial assistance in the amount of $300 for the purchase of Muslim veils and wrap dresses for resale. The requested loan will allow her to increase her self-financing abilities.

Translated from French by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Née en 1970 au Ghana, Madame M. Massawonda est une revendeuse de riz à Tabligbo dans la préfecture de Yoto. Elle est mère de quatre (04) enfants et à sa charge trois (03) autres personnes à charge. Son commerce actuel ne lui permet pas de faire face aux exigences financières de sa famille abandonnée par son mari. Pour développer d’autre projet à part la vente du riz, elle a besoin d’une aide financière de $300 pour l’achat des voiles des musulmans et des pagnes afin de les revendre. Ce crédit demandé lui permettra d’augmenter sa capacité d’autofinancement.

loans.use: Acquire and sell veils and wrap dresses in addition to selling rice

loans.name: Nilufar

texts.en:
Nilufar has been engaging in trading since she was 17 years old, so she has over 30 years of experience in trade. During these years, she tried different kinds of business activity. Currently she rents a big shop and she trades china, toys, perfumes, and sweets. She used her last loan to purchase a refrigerator. She plans to use her new loan to extend her selection of perfumes.

Nilufar has two children. Her girl is 26 years old, and her son is 32.

loans.use: Expand perfume selection

loans.name: Flor De Maria

texts.es:
FLOR DE MARIA IS 33 YEARS OLD. SHE IS MARRIED AND HER HUSBAND WORKS AS A CONSTRUCTION ASSISTANT. SHE PREPARES AND DELIVERS MEALS TO CUSTOMERS THAT HAVE PLACED AN ORDER. SHE INTENDS TO USE HER LOAN TO PURCHASE KITCHENWARE AND ADDITIONAL STORAGE CONTAINERS SO SHE CAN HAUL HER LOAD OF DELIVERIES MORE EFFICIENTLY. SHE IS PART OF GROUP SUPERACION 6 - ALONG WITH LETICIA ROVELO CONSTANTINO ( FOOD SUPPLY STORE ), JOSEFA L. H. ( FOOD SUPPLY STORE ) AND JOSEFA DE JESUS URBINA ( FOOD SUPPLY STORE ). THEY WANT TO PURCHASE MORE NON-PERISHABLE FOOD ITEMS AND MORE MERCHANDISE IN GENERAL TO BETTER EQUIP THEIR BUSINESSES.

Translated from Spanish by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer.

FLOR DE MARIA TIENE 33 AÑOS , CASADA 2 HIJOS SU ESPOSO TRABAJA COMO AYUDANTE DE ALBAÑIL.ELLA PREPARA ALIMENTOS EN SU CASA Y POSTERIORMENTE LOS LLEVA A DOMICILIO SEGÚN LOS PEDIDOS QUE LE HAGAN . ELLA ESPERA CON SU PARTE DEL PRESTAMO INVERTIR EN UTENSILIOS DE COCINA Y ENVASES PARA PODER TRASLADAR DE MEJOR MANERA LOS ALIMENTOS QUE ENTREGA . FORMA PARTE DEL GRUPO SUPERACION 6 JUNTO CON LETICIA ROVELO CONSTANTINO ( TIENDA DE ABARROTES ) JOSEFA L. H. (TIENDA DE ABARROTES ) Y JOSEFA DE JESUS URBINA ( TIENDA DE ABARROTES )ELLAS ESPERAN INVERTIR COMPRANDO ALIMENTOS NO PERECIBLES Y MERCADERIA PARA ABASTECER SUS NEGOCIOS.

loans.use: VENTA DE COMIDA

loans.name: Hoa Thi

texts.vi:
With a loan of 50 USD, Ms Hoa Thi M. opened her first stand, selling goods, 13 years ago. She could never imagine that one day she would be an owner of a big store like the one today. "I was only 23, newly wed. I had no experience". She did not have a house nor any land, her only hope was that the revenue from her little stand would be enough to cover her daily expenses. Hard working, determination and discipline had enabled her to always repay her loan on time every week. Because of this, her fund limit raised higher and higher each round. Her revenue grew and grew. Ms M. had purchased a 150 square meters space in a prime location in Sóc Sơn. She had built a 3 storey house with a store selling goods on the first floor. Her 2 children don't have to worry about the expenses for their schooling anymore. Ms M. is requesting a loan of 1200 USD to buy more products for her store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Bắt đầu với mức vốn vay 50 USD để mở một hiệu tạp hóa nhỏ cách đây 13 năm, có lẽ không khi nào chị Hoa Thi M. lại hình dung ra mình sẽ là chủ một cửa hàng lớn như bây giờ: "Khi ấy tôi mới lập gia đình, mới 23 tuổi, chưa có kinh nghiệm kinh doanh". Không có nhà, không có đất, chị Hoa chỉ mong nguồn thu nhập từ hiệu tạp hóa nhỏ bé này đủ để trang trải cho những khoản chi phí hàng ngày. Với tính cần cù, chịu khó, năng nhặt chặt bị giúp chị quen dần với cách hoàn trả tuần của Quỹ Tình thương. Mức vốn vay qua các vòng được tăng dần, hiệu quả kinh tế ngày càng cao, chị Hoa đã mua được 150 mét đất mặt đường huyện Sóc Sơn. Chị đã xây được nhà 3 tầng và dành một diện tích 50 mét cho việc bán hàng. Hai con của chị giờ đây cũng không phải lo lắng khi xin mẹ tiền học phí. Chị đang xin vay mức vốn 1200 USD để tăng lượng hàng xuất nhập hàng ngày.

loans.use: buy confectionary, wine, milk for her grocery store

loans.name: Junu Maiya

texts.en: Mrs. Junu Maiya S., 33, lives in Kalimati. Kalimati is located in Kathmandu Valley. Kalimati is a very popular market for selling vegetables and fruits. Mrs. S. lives in a home with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Prem Bahadur S., is a taxi driver. He drives a taxi around Kathmandu Valley. Her daughter has completed an SLC (School Leaving Certificate) this year and her son is in grade 6. Now she needs a $175 loan to help her husband with the maintenance of his taxi.

loans.use: To repair a taxi

loans.name: Christian Rural

texts.en:
Yakubu Abdulai is a trader at moree junction near cape coast. She sells provisions such as milk, milo, frytol cooking oil, oaths, pepsodent, tape batteries, bulbs, detol, cheese etc. He is married with two children ages 9 and 5 years respectively. The wife is also a trader who manages another store owned by her husband.
Yakubu is a hardworking man. He also sells groundnut, maize, beans, yam etc. He brings them from the northern part of the country and supplies them to some junior and senior high schools within and outside cape coast. He is a well known trader. He also sells cosmetics, mineral water, minerals such as coco cola, malt, fanta etc.
One major challenge that yakubu faces is the high cost (transportation cost) of bringing the foodstuffs from the northern part of the country to supply his customers, schools etc.
He is therefore asking for a loan of US $ 1,200 dollars to enable him pay for the high cost of transportation, bring in more food such as maize, yam, groundnut, sweet potatoes to supply to the junior and senior high schools. He also wants to buy more creams and body lotions to fill his cosmetic store.

loans.use: Buy foodstuffs (maize, yam, groundnut, sweet potatoes) to supply to his customers (junior and senior high schools)

loans.name: Padi Bali Group

texts.id:
The farmer group "PADI BALI" is headed by I Wajan P.. The member of this farmer group is: I Wajan P., I Gede Ketut S., I Wajan S., I Gede Nyoman S., I Ketut A., I Wayan W., I Ketut S., I Nyoman B., I Gede Ketut W., I Wayan B., I Gede Ketut S., I Ketut W..

As Balinese farmers, they do the farming as a group in accordance with the decision made by their village. This approach is beneficial to all. The water is distributed fairly. Up to now they do the farming in a convensional way. They use bufallo to work on their field.

With the loan money, they are planning to buy a tractor, costing them IDR 8 million (approx. US$ 840). Indeed not everyone will have a tractor, but this tractor will be used together by the group.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Kelompok tani Padi Bali yang diketuai I Wayan P. ini beranggotakan : I Wayan P., I Gede Ketut S., I Wayan S., I Gede Nyoman S., I Ketut A., I Wayan W., I Ketut S., I Nyoman B., I Gede Ketut W., I Wayan B., I Gede Ketut S., I Ketut W.. Sebagai petani Bali mereka melakukan penanaman secara serempak sesuai dengan keputusan adat. Tentu saja hal ini akan sangat menguntungkan semua pihak. Air akan mereka bagi dengan adil. Pengolahan lahan yang selama ini mereka lakukan adalah dengan menggunakan cara konvensional. Mereka masih menggunakan kerbau untuk membajak sawah mereka. Melalui pinjaman yang diperoleh, mereka berencana mempermudah pekerjaan mereka dengan membeli sebuah traktor senilai Rp 8.000.000,00. Memang tidak setiap orang akan memiliki traktor, melainkan dari satu traktor yang ada akan di manfaatkan bersama.

loans.use: to buy a tractor, seeds and fertilizer (membeli sebuah traktor, bibit, dan pupuk)

loans.name: Namunina A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Florence Namusko. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to increase her inventory. Florence is 38 years old and is single. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 30,000 in profits.

Florence is joined in her small group by Lillian N., Elizabeth N., Christine N., and Fatumah N.. Lillian N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to expand her stone business. Elizabeth N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying as well. She is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to re-invest in her stone quarry business. Christine N. is also currently in the business of stone quarrying. Christine is requesting a loan of UGX 700,000 to expand her business. Finally, Fatumah N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to buy more land for her stone quarrying business.

loans.use: To invest in the businesses

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jaqueline has a general store in Tarapotillo, San Martin. Tarapotillo is a neighborhood outside the city of Tarapoto. In the store she sells fruits, vegetables, rice, oil, sodas, hygiene products and much more. Clients are happy they can buy the majority of their goods from Jaqueline instead of walking all the way into Tarapoto.  

Jaqueline is 33 years old, married, and has one young child. She started the store 8 years ago in the living room of her home. She has recently built a room especially for the store with shelves and display cases. She loves being able to work from home and care for her child. One day Jaqueline dreams of sending her child to a University.

A member of the community bank Mujeres Decididas, Jaqueline is requesting a loan of S/. 1,000 to repay over 6 months. She will use the loan to restock her shelves with the goods the population of Tarapotillo love.

loans.use: She will use the loan to restock her shelves

loans.name: Dora Lisbet

texts.en:
Dora Lisbet Fevres M. owns a general store that she runs with her daughter in the city of Pucallpa, Ucayali.  She started the store 10 years ago with the help of her husband who has recently passed away.  

Dora is 50 years old, healthy, happy to have her store and work with her daughter. She loves socializing with her clients and building relationships. Dora will continue to invest in her business and make her clients happy.

A member of the community bank Mujeres Empresarias, Dora is requesting a loan of s/1500 to repay over 6 months.  She would like to use the extra capital to buy sugar, rice, sodas and everything else that she sells at her store.

loans.use: She would like to use the extra capital to buy sugar, rice, sodas and everything else that she sells at her store.

loans.name: Arafa

texts.en:
Arafa, age 20, is married with a toddler. She runs a charcoal and soup business, where she sells these items from 7am to 10pm daily. From this business, which started 6 months ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $110.

Arafa hopes for a loan to purchase more charcoal and more food ingredients for her business. She is a member of the Letu Moja loan group. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and food items

loans.name: Adjowa

texts.en:
Adjowa A. extracts palm oil. She sells her oil to a local soap manufacturer. She is married, but her husband's income from farming is not sufficient to cover the expenses of Adjowa and her eight dependents. Demand for her palm oil is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Flor De Mayo Group

texts.en:
The women of the Flor D. Mayo Group have worked together for nearly five years and are now requesting their eighth loan from Friendship Bridge. Of the seven women in the group, two sew pants and shirts, two embroider traditional blouses, two buy clothing in bulk for resale, and one grows and sells vegetables and chickens. All of the women sell their products in the local market in Santa Lucia, and some travel to nearby Nahualá to have access to a larger market.

These women range in age from 26 to 54 years old and all but one of them are married and have children. About half of them have had at least a little education, although none has completed more than the sixth graD.. Those who have not had any formal education cannot read or write, and sign all paperwork with a fingerprint. Regardless of how much education each woman has had, every one of them has maD. her children’s education a top priority. All of those with school-age children are currently able to pay for the registration fees and school supplies needed to send them to school.

When asked why they are seeking loans, they enthusiastically say that, more than anything, it’s for their children. Before they had access to credit, many were unable to pay the small costs associated with sending their children to school. Now, with the help of loans, they are able to work more and fight for a better future for their children. More directly, those working in clothing-related industries will use their loans to purchase cloth, thread, patterns and clothes in bulk, while the woman selling vegetables and chickens will use her loan to buy seeds, fertilizer and more chickens.

Several of the women also report that, in addition to being able to expand their businesses and send their children to school, having access to credit has enabled them to make improvements on their houses, such as getting better roofs or buying more cinder blocks to have more solid walls. When asked what they like most about working together in the Flor D. Mayo group, they all agreed that it is a great group because everyone always pays on time and there is a lot of trust among the members. They also report that they have found the informal education programs that Friendship Bridge offers at the regular group meetings to be very helpful. Not only have they learned basic business administration and money management skills, but several say that their favorite lesson of all was learning about natural medicines such as plants, some of which they already had on hand although they never knew the benefit they could proviD..

When asked about their dreams, these women report that more than anything they hope their children won’t suffer as they have suffered. They are “fighting” so that their children can advance, receive good educations, and someday be professionals with more security and a higher quality of living.

loans.use: To purchase cloth, thread, patterns and clothing in bulk and buy seeds, fertilizer and chickens

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia baji is the wife of S. M. and has lived in Borewala for the past 3 years. She owns a two room brick house. She is the mother of two sons. Her elder son, who is 19 years old, works with Warid Telecommunication Company. Razia baji’s husband is also an employee in this company. Her next eldest son, who is 18 years old, wants to start a barber shop. Therefore, she is applying for a loan for her son to buy materials to start this business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members: Yasmeen baji wants a loan to buy wooden furniture to resell; Salma baji wants a loan to buy more chickens to resell; Farzana baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart; and Shahida baji wants a loan to buy more vegetables for her vegetable business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Rufina Margarita

texts.es:
Rufina is 33 years old, living with her husband and 3 children. She is a hard-working woman who is always seeking to make a significant contribution to the household finances. She does so with her embroidery, which began as a hobby helping one of her friends, then she realized that this work is profitable as well as enjoyable. She did not hesitate to begin her own business producing "talqueado" embroideries for costume parties called "Santiagos".

She has seen a profit from these 3 years of intense work and today her husband also encourages her to keep embroidering. He also engages in agricultural work and in the sale of firewood. In spite of the short time that her childcare leaves Rufina, she never stops working in her own home every day creating these beautiful embroideries, which realize their profit when they are sold after a month's labor.

Rufina's motivation is to give the best to her three children in school. She is requesting this loan in order to invest in the purchase of the supplies necessary for her work, such as fabrics and colored wool yarn. She will also invest a part in her husband's firewood business.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

Rufina tiene 33 años y en la actualidad vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos. Es una mujer muy laboriosa que siempre busca aportar significativamente en la economía del hogar, y lo hace mediante los bordados, todo comenzó para ella como una afición, ayudando a una de sus familiares, luego vio que este trabajo era rentable y además, le agradaba, no dudó entonces en emprender ella misma su negocio, produce talqueados que son los fustanes bordados para una fiesta costumbrista que se llama Santiago, ha visto la ganancia de estos 3 años de intenso trabajo y su esposo hoy también es su aliado para seguir bordando, pese a que su esposo también se dedica a las tareas agrícolas y a la venta de leña, a pesar del corto tiempo que dispone Rufina atiende a sus hijos, no deja de trabajar en su propia casa todos los días realizando estos bellos bordados que después de un mes de labor puede ver sus frutos cuando cobra por ello. El motivo del esfuerzo de Rufina es dar lo mejor a sus 3 hijos que están estudiando. Solicita este préstamo será invertido en la compra de los insumos necesarios para su trabajo, como telas, lanas de diversos colores, etc. y una parte también será para invertir en el negocio de leña de su esposo.

loans.use: Purchase of materials for her embroideries, wool and other fabrics, as well as to invest with her husband in a business to sell firewood.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To aquire a larger stock of clothing to sell in her community

loans.name: Brigida

texts.es:
Brígida es socia del Banco Comunal Nuevo Amanecer, es casada tiene 3 hijos de 35,30 y 20 años , su último hijo está en la universidad. Brígida hace 15 años empezó con el negocio de servicio de taxi , Brígida tiene 3 carros y su esposo maneja unos de ellos , también tiene un local que lo alquila a carros interprovinciales y ahora va entrar en el negocio de alquiler de departamentos.

Brígida desde que recibe los préstamos ha mejorado y ha logrado tener más capital de trabajo. Brígida necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en el acabado de un departamento que piensa alquilar . Brígida sueña con construir departamentos para alquilar pues tiene un local grande.
texts.en:
Brigida is a member of the community bank "Nuevo Amanecer" (A New Dawn). She is married and she has 3 children aged 35, 30 and 20 years old. The youngest is currently in university.

Brigida started her taxi service business 15 years ago. She owns 3 cars and her husband drives one of them. She also has a stand that she rents out to to interprovincial taxis. And now she plans on renting out apartments.

Since Brigida started receiving loans she has improved her business and she has managed to have greater working capital.

She requires a loan in the amount of 2000 soles, funds that will be invested in the remodelling of an apartment she hopes to rent out.

Brigida dreams with building more apartments to rent out on her spacious property.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Brigida requires a loan amounting to 2000 soles, funds that will be invested in the remodelling of an apartment she wishes to rent out.

loans.name: Aissa

texts.fr: Mariée et mere de six (06)enfants aissa est agée 48 ans elle s 'active dans la vente des huilles de palme  depuis 10 ans .Le produit est acheté par les femmes du quartier qui l utilisent dans la préparation des repas.Le pret denandé servira  à renforcer son fond de roulement par l 'achat de quantité plus importante de marchandise pour faire face à la forte demande des clients.
texts.en:
Aissa is 48 years old, married, and the mother of six children. She has been selling palm oil for 10 years. Palm oil is bought by neighbourhood women who use it in meal preparation. The loan will be used to bolster her working capital by purchasing more merchandise to meet the high demand of her customers.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred, a 35 year old storeowner, is married to Serafin, a tricycle driver and manager of their welding shop as well as village treasurer. Their marriage is gifted with three children: Shermae Michelle – a 16-year-old first year nursing student; Sermil Micheal – a 13-year-old junior high school student, and Shella Mae – a 10-year-old Grade 4 elementary student. The family lives in Barangay Magsaysay Naguillan, Isabela.

Mildred’s store has been a big help in their family, as each week she can earn a gross income of at least $320, budgeting that income to support the studies of her eldest, since the nursing course is very expensive, and for the educational needs of her other two children. Some of the earnings are also used to maintain their corn and rice farming business.

To further sustain her store and farming business, Mildred is requesting a loan as additional capital with which she will buy more stocks to offer in her store. The said amount will make her store profitable and hopefully enable her to convert it into a grocery store. In this way, she can provide for the immediate needs of the people in the community and make it more convenient for them because they will not have to go to the market just to acquire their basic requirements.

Through the income from her business, Mildred is able to provide the medication for her eldest child who is suffering from lupus, a chronic auto-immune disease that can be fatal. She prays that they can prevail in their struggle and that her child will be cured. She loves her family and becomes teary- eyed whenever she remembers her child's sickness. According to Mildred, her child is strongly fighting her sickness and this gives her the strength to overcome it.

loans.use: To buy more stocks for her store.

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
El señor Julio Cesar se dedica al igual que su esposa la señora Flor a la venta de barbacoa y de chicharrones desde hace 8 años, lo cual atribuye la gran clientela y contratación de otros dos trabajadores ya que la venden por toda la ciudad en sus respectivos carros para asi lograr venderla por todas las colonias.
El anteriormente había solicitado un crédito para la educación de sus hijos, crédito que fue pagado siempre con puntualidad, y ahora esta solicitando este para la colocación de una losa de concreto de un cuarto para ampliarse en su hogar y darle mayor comodidad a su familia.
texts.en:
Julio Cesar, together with his wife Flor, has sold barbeque and crackling for the past eight years. They have many customers and have hired two helpers as they now sell throughout the city from their respective cars. He had a previous loan for his children's education which was always repaid on time and he is now asking for a loan to pour a concrete slab for a new bedroom to add to his home and make it more comfortable for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To have a concrete slab poured for his home.

loans.name: Tural

texts.en: Tural is single and lives in Khachmaz town. This man was born in 1979. He has run this business for 5 years. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy fruits and vegetables to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables for re-sale

loans.name: Ni Ketut Bentri

texts.id: Sebagai wanita Bali beragama Hindu, Ketut Bentri mempunyai usaha membuat jajan uli untuk perlengkapan banten.Bentri sudah ikut bergabung dengan Yayasan Dinari dan masuk di KWT Tiing Gading sudah periode kedua dan pembayaran dilakukan setiap bulan dengan jangka waktu 12 bulan. Setiap hari Bentri membuat jajan dari pagi sampai siang dan selanjutnya jajan diiris tipis-tipis sesuai dengan ukurannya , kemudian dijemur sampai kering. Modal yang dipakai Rp.500.000,- , Banyak langganan yang membeli jajan ulinya 100 biji harganya Rp.11.000 dan 1000 biji harganya Rp.110.000,-. Bentri sanggup membuat jajan uli sampai 1000 biji per hari. Keuntungan yang diperoleh sebesar Rp.50.000,- perhari. Keuntungannya dipakai untuk memenuhi kebutuhannya dan untuk pendidikan anaknya yang masih sekolah di SMEA dan di SMP .Keinginannya untuk memperbaiki rumahnya agar lebih bagus dan nyaman untuk ditempati.Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri dengan bangunan yang cukup sederhana. Harapannya dengan pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari , Bentri akan lebih menambah usahanya dan lebih banyak melayani pelanggannya.

loans.use: be the capital to buy more ingredients

loans.name: Noel Alberto

texts.es:
En el municipio de San Rafael en Managua el señor Noel R. se dedica a su actividad de ganadería habiéndose dedicado con mucho empeño a su actividad desde hace varios años. Es de importancia destacar que el señor Noel lha logrado salir adelante ya que es viudo y con un hijo que mantener.

Hoy en día el motivo por el cual ha acudido a Ceprodel es para ser beneficiado con un crédito para la compra de una ternera ya que requiere obtenerla para así continuar en su actividad  y por esto espera que su crédito sea otorgado lo mas pronto posible para así continuar beneficiando a su pequeño hijo en su municipio.
texts.en:
In the municipality of San Rafael in Managua Mr. Noel Ramirez has been raising cattle with much effort for some years. It is important to emphasize that Mr. Noel has managed to get ahead even though he is a widower and has a child to support.

Today the reason he is turning to Ceprodel is to benefit from a loan to purchase a calf that he requires to continue his business. For this reason he is hoping to be granted the loan as soon as possible so that he can continue to provide for his small child in his municipality.

Translated from Spanish by Breanne Kochert, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of a calf.

loans.name: Hidjran

texts.en: Hidjran is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Fizuli region of the occupied territory of Azerbaijan. She is settled in the Kayidish village, built for IDPs. Hidjran was born in 1971 and is the mother of three children. Five years ago she started a business breeding cattle. Now she needs a loan of $2500 to buy three calves to improve her  business.

loans.use: To buy three calves

loans.name: Ruta

texts.en: Ruta S., 21, is married with two children.  She has five years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and public, one day per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 tala (~$25 US).  SPBD loans are Ruta’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals, weed killer, spade, electric chain saw and sacks of fertilizer

loans.name: Moynatou

texts.fr:
A. Moynatou est née vers 1960 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Moynatou est mariée à AFFOTON Kabirou, chauffeur de profession. Moynatou est mère de quatre(04) enfants dont trois garçons et une fille. Les deux aînés sont majeurs; seuls les deux derniers enfants, à savoir Toundé et Kèfil sont encore à la charge des parents. Toundé et Kèfil sont respectivement en classe de terminale et de première année du lycée. Moynatou assure avec son mari les charges de la famille. Moynatou vend de l'alcool médical en détail et en gros. C'est à la PHARMAQUIK une entreprise de fabrication des médicaments génériques au Bénin que Moynatou s'approvisionne en alcool. Moynatou a eu déjà trois crédits de ALIDé; crédits qu'elle a bien remboursé et avec lesquels elle a pu amener son activité à un stade supérieur. Aujourd'hui Moynatou  sollicite un quatrième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de commerce et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Ainsi Moynatou va pourvoir augmenter son revenu pour mieux satisfaire les besoins de sa famille. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500.
texts.en:
A. Moynatou was born around 1960 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to AFFOTON Kabirou, a chauffeur by profession. She is the mother of four children (3 boys and a girl). The two oldest are of age; only the last two children, namely Toundé and Kèfil, are still supported by their parents. Toundé and Kèfil are respectively in the last year and the first year of high school. Moynatou and her husband ensure that family expenses are met.

Moynatou sells medical alcohol retail and wholesale. There, at the PHARMAQUIK (an enterprise that makes generic medicines in Benin), she acquires her supplies of alcohol. She has already had three ALIDÉ loans, which she repaid and which she used to bring her business along to a higher level. Today, she's requesting a fourth loan to bolster her working capital and to satisfy her customers better. Thus, she's going to be able to increase her revenues to do better in meeting family needs.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two drums of alcohol

loans.name: Rosa Adela

texts.es: La Señora Rosa D. tiene 44 años de edad, habita en el barrio Villa Reconciliación en la capital de Managua, casada, tiene cuatros hijos. Con bases seguras quiere terminar de construir su casa para tener un patrimonio para sus hijos. Tiene su pequeño negocio de ropas, zapatos y bisutería desde hace siete años tiene la iniciativa de venta ya que tenia un tramo de ropa en el mercado el cual vendió y  trasferirla ha su casa. Gracias al préstamo que solicita en Afodenic lograra comprar mercaderías como: ropa para damas y caballeros, perfumes, zapatos, sandalias y prendas. Es su doceavo ciclo el cual da las gracias a la institución por los créditos otorgado y por los beneficios adquiridos.

loans.use: Comprar ropa, zapatos, perfumes y otros productos

loans.name: Adilia Judith

texts.es:
ADILIA JUDITH, pertenece al Banco Comunal “MUIJERES VALIENTES” vive en el Jr. Coronel Portillo Nº 836, en la ciudad D. Pucallpa, tiene 45 años D. edad, 2 hijos y su pareja es técnico agropecuario.

Se inició en el negocio D. venta D. productos “UNION” y el primer préstamo D. S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, compró algunos productos para venderlos a sus vecinos, también está ingresando al negocio D. la venta D. productos D. belleza.
Hoy, ella ha progresado con su familia y el negocio D. la venta D. productos D. belleza ha mejorado. 

Con este préstamo  D. S/.1,200.00 Nuevos Soles, lo invertirá en la compra D. perfumes, cosméticos y nuevos productos.

“Manuela Ramos es una ONG, que apoya a una gran cantidad D. familias, con pequeños préstamos que permite a las mujeres D. esta zona a iniciar o a mejorar sus negocios, y estoy contenta con esa ayuda” refirió.
texts.en:
Adila Judith belongs to the “Brave Women” Communal Bank and lives on Coronel Portillo Street in the city of Pucallpa. She is 45 years old, has 2 children, and her husband is an agricultural worker. She started selling “Union” products and with the first loan of 300 new soles she bought some products to sell to her neighbors. She is also starting a business selling beauty products. Today she has maD. progress with her family and the beauty products business has improved. With this loan of 1,200 new soles, she will invest in the purchase of perfumes, cosmetics and new products. She said, “Manuela Ramos is an NGO [Non-governmental organization] that supports a great number of families with small loans that allow women of this area to start or improve businesses and I am happy with this assistance.”

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy perfumes, cosmetics, and new beauty products

loans.name: Shkerullah Group

texts.en:
Shkerullah is the group leader of Shkerullah group. There are six members in this group and they all want to expand their businesses. They are requested a group of loan 60,000 Afghani.

Shkerullah wants to take a loan for his fruit and vegetables shop.

Moh Gul wants to take a loan for her husband who has a truck.

Gul Hara wants to take a loan for her bakery business.

M. Uaqab wants to take a loan for his carpet-weaving business.

Bebe Shah wants to take a loan for her tailoring business.

Abdul Maten wants to take a loan for his carpentry business.

They are very thankful to AFS and Kiva lenders who are able to support all the world.

loans.use: To expand his fruit and vegetables shop

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a 40 year old woman married to Maleno, a laborer, and they have four children ranging in age from 14-9. They live in a rural but very beautiful village of Hamtic in the Antique province in the Philippines. She has had her business since 2005 of selling vegetables in her village, but it was hard to gain extra capital to buy more goods and be able to increase her profit.

With this loan from ASHI of 12,000 Pesos, she will be able to buy a larger quantity of vegetables and also is going to buy a few small piglets for pig fattening, a popular business here. She will buy them seed, supplements and vitamins and sell them after about six months when they are ready to go to market.

Her greatest hope is to rise out of poverty. With more of her vegetables in production and this extra source of income from the hogs, she believes she will be able to save money to send her kids to school and hopefully one day college.

Written by Sloane Berrent, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: To buy piglets and vegetables.

loans.name: 026 Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Cúc Vũ Thị is a 47 year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Cúc is the group leader of a six-member group loan request offered by Kiva partner the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 26 (026 Quảng Hưng).

Cúc is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Cúc operates a family member's livestock raising business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes primarily from raising cattle for sale. Cúc has been doing this business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2005, Cúc joined Kiva Partner the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cúc has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. She is now requesting a loan of 6,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. The loan will be her seventh loan from Kiva partner the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Cúc plans to use the additional revenue to improve her general living conditions.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1. N. Thị Vấn is a 36 year-old female requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her service-based business.

2. Ngô Thị Hà is a 28 year-old female requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her livestock raising business.

3. H. Thị Lan is a 27 year-old female requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her service-based business.

4. N. Thị Phượng is a 34 year-old female requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her livestock raising business.

5. P. Thị Lâm is a 27 year-old female requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her livestock raising business.

About the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas of Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Cúc Vũ Thị (53) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Cúc là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 26 (026 Quảng Hưng).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán. Cúc thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Cúc kiếm được khoảng 3000000 VND. Vào 2005, Cúc đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Cúc đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 7th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1. N. Thị Vấn (78) là 36 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

2. Ngô Thị Hà (74) là 28 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

3. H. Thị Lan (73) là 27 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

4. N. Thị Phượng (75) là 34 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

5. P. Thị Lâm (87) là 27 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

."If you would like to translate the Vietnamese text above, please visit the free online translator offered by Vdict.com.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en: Nadia J. is currently in the business of selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase brewing materials. She is 28 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has two children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more brewing materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk

loans.name: Nob

texts.en: R. is a 35-year-old single man who lives with his mother, Seoun, 61, a seller of fermented fish (pra hoc in Khmer language). He has three brothers and a sister, all of whom are married and live separately. R. is the youngest of the three brothers. He makes his livelihood by running a motorbike taxi service in his community. His only dream and future plan is to support his sister, who is currently in school, in going to university. He has recently taken a loan to buy a motorbike for his business.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for his business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: La señora Dolly, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Pequeñas Empresarias II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 44 años, 01 hijo, que aun depende de ella.Dolly, se dedica a la venta de pasajes aéreos,  nos comenta que para iniciarse, empezó de muy poco. Ya que anteriormente, trabajaba en una agencia de viajes, posteriormente Dolly, estableció su propia Agencia, en su misma casa, en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado, para atender a sus clientes,  esta muy orgullosa y contenta por haber salido adelante con el apoyo  Manuela Ramos que le ayudo bastante a mejorar su servicio.En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio, contando para esto con clientes ya fidelizados, que a diario acude a su casa a comprar sus pasajes y  es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza. Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000.00, comprará pasajes aéreos.Parte del dinero también lo invertirá pagando la mensualidad, de su computadora, herramienta principal de su trabajo.Dolly, hoy en día se siente una mujer muy realizada, supo salir adelante y hoy se siente con ganas de hacer realidad sus demás sueños y metas que tiene trazada en la vida.

loans.use: Comprará pasajes aereos.

loans.name: Ramon Alberto

texts.es: Ramón Alberto tiene la edad de 35 años, es un hombre casado. Ramón tiene 2 hijos. La actividad económica es compra y venta de ropa. El  dio inicio este negocio por que no tenía un trabajo, y su esposa y su hijo necesitaban el sustento diario, a pesar de lo difícil que es su situación Ramón mantiene la alegría con sus clientes. Hace más de 6 años que se dedica a este negocio y lo más difícil de su trabajo es que tiene que recorrer muchos kilómetros en busca de sus clientes. El financiamiento que solicita es destinado para capital de trabajo para la compra de ropa interior, calzado entre otros. A pesar de los difíciles problemas que enfrenta como las cuentas por cobrar. Los sueños de Ramón son de proporcionarle a su familia las condiciones de vida necesarias.
texts.en:
Ramón Alberto is 35 and married. Ramón has two children. He buys and sells clothes. He started this business because he did not have work, and he needed to provide for his wife and son. In spite of how difficult Ramón’s situation is, Ramón is always cheerful with his customers. He has had this business for over six months. The most difficult thing about his work is having to travel so many kilometers looking for customers. In spite of the problems he faces like settling customer accounts, he will use the loan as working capital to buy underwear and footwear among other things. Ramon’s dreams are to give his family the living conditions that are a necessity.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Laura Maria

texts.es: Laura Maria M. L., ella tiene 45 años de edad, tiene 4 hijos y todos trabajan de manera independiente. Ella se dedica a la venta productos lácteos. Hace más de 4 años que se dedica a este negocio, el cual dio inicio vendiendo bolsas de leche y fue a partir de ese momento que fue reinvirtiendo en su negocio para hacerlo más grande, y poder vivir de ese negocio, ya que los trabajos están escasos en nuestro país. El crédito será invertido en la compra principalmente de más productos. El sueño es que su negocio crezca y si Dios lo permite, convertirse en una distribuidora de productos al por mayor de sus productos.
texts.en:
Laura Maria M. L. is 45 years old and has 4 children who all work independently. She has been selling dairy products for more than 4 years. Laura started her business selling bags of milk, and from that point, she kept reinvesting so that she could make it bigger. This became her means of earning a living since jobs are scarce throughout the country. Her loan will be used to buy more dairy products. She dreams of growing her business, and God willing, becoming a wholesale dairy distributor.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to acquire more dairy products

loans.name: Ernesto Jose

texts.es: El señor Ernesto R. es un padre de familia de una niña de 8 años de edad, lo cual junto con su esposa están trabajando para poder terminar de hacer su casa. El trabaja en café soluble  desde de abastecedor de productos en todos los departamentos. Cuando inicio  fue un largo periodo de  prueba hasta que logro quedarse fijo. Su esposa trabaja en zona franca y su hija la cuida un familiar.  Su casa es pequeña ha ido poco a poco le falta repellarla en fino, pintar y ponerle piso. Con este financiamiento lograra hacer un bajarete por que le entra mucho el sol y para poder gozar de una tarde menos calientes. Para construir comprara zinc y perlines, tuvo de hierro  para hacer el comienzo para luego cerrarlo. Agradece ala institución por el financiamiento por que solo a través de los préstamos a plazo se logra las mejoras de construcción debido a que los productos están carros.
texts.en:
Ernesto R. and his wife are parents of an 8-year-old girl. They are both working hard to finish building their house. He works in instant coffee, supplying products to all the departments. When he began, he had to pass a long probation period before being hired permanently. His wife works in a free-zone and a friend babysits their daughter. Their house is very small and has been built bit by bit. It still needs to have the final plaster layer applied, needs to be painted, and lacks a floor. This financing will be used to build a shelter to protect against the sun so that they can enjoy their afternoons with less heat. To build, he needs zinc metal sheeting, metal sheets, metal tubing, etc. to start and then close it up. He is grateful to the institution for the financing because it's only thanks to the long-term loans that one can manage home improvements because building materials are very expensive.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim S. is 24 years old and lives with his wife in the Takeo province. He works at a security company and makes $7 a day. His wife stays at home and raises pigs. On average, she earns $4 of profit a day. 

Sim S. would like to take out a loan of $800 to purchase rice. He will purchase rice and take off the husk with the intention of reselling the rice and turning a profit. He is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase his income and raise his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: Sell rice

loans.name: Mayra De La Trinidad

texts.es: Mayra De La Trinidad tiene 45 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos a su cargo, desde muy joven ha sido trabajadora  y en el transcurso de su vida ha emprendido muchos negocios de los cuales no todos le fueron viables por lo que decidió empezar con  ofrecer los servicios de sala de belleza, ella inicio este negocio hace mas 10 años empezó como una aprendiz y poco a poco esta actividad le fue gustando y mejoro cada día. Es así es que ella logra obtener su propio negocio y a lo largo ha podido contar con Fundación León 2000 el cual le ha proveído de muchos financiamientos. El financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra cosméticos, cepillo, tijeras, tintes, shampoo y acondicionadores por lo que en esta temporada recibe a muchos clientes. El deseo de ella es mantener este negocio activo para que sus hijos tengan el sustento diario.
texts.en:
Mayra De la Trinidad is 45 years old. She is a single mother and has two children that she supports. Since she was very young she has been a worker, and through the course of her life she has taken on many businesses, not all of which were viable. For that reason, she decided to start offering beauty salon services. She began in this business more than ten years ago. She started out as an apprentice, and little by little she came to enjoy the work and she improved every day. It was in this way that she managed to get her own business, and throughout it all she has been able to count on Fundación León 2000, which has provided her with many loans. This loan is for capital for her work, for the purchase of cosmetics, brushes, scissors, dyes, shampoo and conditioner, because at this time she is getting many customers. Her wish is to keep her business lively so that her children may get their daily sustenance.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of beauty salon products and instruments.

loans.name: Kikonya C Birungi Aisha Group

texts.en: B. Aisha is twenty-three years old and married, with two children, of whom one is going to school. She owns a grocery, and she has been in business for two years so far. She is using the loan to purchase grocery items, such as beans, flour, charcoal, ground nuts, and so forth. She is adding capital, stocking enough in her grocery store for sale. She is an active and encouraging business lady. Her dream is to purchase a motorcycle for transportation to generate daily income.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items such as beans, flour, charcoal, ground nuts, and so forth

loans.name: Beatrice E.w

texts.en:
Beatrice E.W. Makuha is a cereals businesswoman. She started this in the year 1996 and has never looked back. She moves from market to market with her stock, but her chief locations are the Malanga and Lugulu markets. She says that within these two she has a guaranteed customer base. She buys her stock twice a week at Busia town. 

Beatrice would like a loan of 20,000 KES to expand her business. Her future plan is to venture into poultry farming.

loans.use: Expand her stock of cereals

loans.name: Sarantuya

texts.en:
Sarantuya is 43 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Arhangai province, Mongolia. Sarantuya operates a consumer goods retail business, with the help of her husband, in a rented stall at a local market. They sell different kinds of consumer goods such as socks, shoes, oil, soap, detergent, etc. She began her business in 2002 and over the years, her business has grown and become successful. Now her working capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (about $1,400). In the near future, she is planning to increase her product line and grow her customer base. 

She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more home goods, such as pots, pans, silverware, dishes, etc., for her growing business.

loans.use: To purchase consumer goods

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 41-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their six children. For the last five years, he has made a living running a grocery store where he sells fruits and vegetables, including lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers, peppers, radishes, potatoes, apples, oranges and other items. His customers, most of whom live nearby, like shopping in his store because he has good-quality merchandise. He has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua to buy more merchandise to sell. Ali has always paid loans on time, and plans to keep on improving his work by diversifying his merchandise.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Temukisa

texts.en:
Temukisa P. is 25 and married with 2 children.  She owns a business venture, selling BBQ (sausages, chicken, plantains).  Temukisa has 2 years of experience in this business.  Temukisa needs a loan of WST $1500 to buy BBQ meat, ketchup, plastic plates & utensils, and coal.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 650 talas or US $271 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Temukisa joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Temukisa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Temukisa P. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.7 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy BBQ meat, ketchup, plastic plates & utensils, and coal

loans.name: Torpeki Nasima Group

texts.en:
Torpeki is the group leader of Torpeki Nasima group. She lives in the 11th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and lives in a household of 8 members. She runs a tailoring business from her house. She sews all kinds clothes, both small and big sizes. She is well known among her neighbors for her work and they mostly bring their cloth to her to sew.

 
She wants a loan to purchase another machine because, sometimes, she has problems with the old one. She is glad that this kind of process is really effective for those who want to progress.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Flor De Avispa Group

texts.es:
El grupo Flor de Avispa lo conforman tres mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es Luz Marina Hernández quien recuerda como si fuera ayer como con 300 córdobas inicio su negocio de ropa usada el cual ha ido desarrollando con el tiempo y espera en un futuro no muy lejano tener su propio tramo en el mercado.
Sus compañeras de grupo son Verónica Mercado vende pollo y Ana F. comercializa bolsos y ropa. Ellas invertirán el crédito en la compra de productos para sus negocios.
texts.en:
The Flor de Avispa group is comprised of three hard-working women. One of them is Luz Marina Hernández. She remembers it like it was yesterday when she started her business of used clothing with 300 córdobas. She has been developing it with time, and she hopes in the near future to have her own stall in the market. One of her colleagues in the bank is Verónica Mercado. She sells chicken. Her other colleague is Ana F.. She sells purses and clothes. They will use the loan to buy products for their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bundles of clothes

loans.name: Dos De Mayo Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios pertenecen al banco comunal “DOS DE MAYO”; Nuestros socios viven en la ciudad de Cusco, en el distrito de Huanchac. Los socios se reúnen todos los meses en el local de Arariwa.

Nuestra socia es la Sra. Martha, nuestra socia tiene 43 años de edad es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos Nuestra socia alterna sus actividades de hogar con el comercio minorista, la socia vende productos nutricionales, Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para viajar y comprar productos de nutrición para implementar en su negocio.

Los socios alternan sus actividades con el comercio minorista ellos venden celulares y accesorios, otra socia es empleada de maquinarias pesadas, otra tiene tienda abarrotes, otro socio vende libros y diarios en un kiosko, otros dos socios son fotógrafos, y otra socia vende ropa. Nuestros socios solicitan el préstamo para invertir en sus diferentes negocios.

Los socios  agradecen y valoran el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our members make up the “DOS DE MAYO” (May 2) communal bank. They live in Cusco’s Huanchac district and meet monthly in Arariwa’s offices. Our featured member is Martha, 43. She is a single mother of two children. She alternates her household chores with retail: she sells nutritional products. She is asking for funds to pay travel costs to buy nutritional products to stock her business. The other members alternate their activities with retail. Some sell cell phones and accessories, another member is a heavy machinery operator, one has a grocery store and another member sells books and newspapers in a kiosk; two other members are photographers and one sells clothing. All the members seek funding to invest in their various businesses. The members are grateful for and value the support given them through this means and pledge to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For travel costs to buy nutritional products to stock her business.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita B. is from the town of Banga. She is 61 years old. Anita is married and has 8 adult children. To make a living, Anita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for more than a few years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In September 2008, Anita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Anita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Anita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Maria Tereza

texts.es:
Doña Maria es madre de familia de cuatro hijos, de edad de 54 años, para ella no ha sido fácil, ha tenido que trabajar desde joven para apoyar a sus hijos, hoy en día casados, pero siempre apoyándolos. Desde hace vaR. años logro poner su propio negocio una pulpería que a través de los financiamientos ha aumentado su inventario ya que comenzó con poco  dinero de su liquidación y ayuda de su esposo.

Desde horas tempranas se levanta para vender. En los últimos meses no ha vendido lo suficiente, las ventas han bajado es por eso desea comprar mas productos en granos básicos, lácteos, golosinas, productos enlatados y otros para aumentar sus ventas con los productos de rotamientos  ya que son muchos los gastos que pagar de agua, luz, alimentación y otros.
Entre sus planes, es lograr el aumento de inventario, así como hacer mejoras a su casa como pintarla para que se vea bonita.
texts.en:
Maria is a 54 year old mother of four. Life has not been easy for her. Since she was young, she has had to work to support her children, even though they are now married. A few years back, she was able to start her own business, a pulpería [small grocery store] that because of funding has allowed her to increase her stock. She started it with some money from a settlement and with her husband's help. Maria wakes up in the early morning hours to sell. In the past months she has not sold enough. Because sales have dropped, she would like to buy more basic products like dry grains, dairy products, sweets, canned goods, and other things. This is to increase sales by rotating goods, since there are many costs to pay for water, light, food, and more. Among her plans is to gain an increase in stock in order to improve her home by painting it so that it will look pretty.

Translated from Spanish by Flavia Garcia, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of dry grains, canned goods, sweets, chickens, meat, and more to increase her sales

loans.name: La Presa De Chosto Group

texts.es:
Este grupo de llama La Presa de Chosto, se ubica en el Estado de México. Esta comunidad se distingue por que existía una presa (hace 20 años). El grupo está conformado por 10 integrantes. 
María de los Ángeles M. es la presidenta del grupo. Tiene 39 años, estudió hasta el 6to año de primaria, es casada y tiene un hijo. Ella se dedica a la venta de bordados que inició hace 6 años. Solicita el préstamo para comprar hilos, servilletas, manteles, etc. 
La  señora Julia L.  integrante del grupo arriba mencionado se dedica a la venta de ropa que inició hace 12 años. Solicita el préstamo para comprar pantalones, camisas, suéteres para dama y caballero. Tiene alrededor de 100 clientes en las localidades de Chosto, La Mesa y Lanzados; poco a poco se dio a conocer en la región inicialmente tenía un taller de costura (hace 15 años) en el cual se maquilaba ropa, sin embargo por cuestiones personales se cerró el negocio y se repartió el capital entre los socios, de ahí les surgió la idea de vender ropa. Al momento de solicitar este préstamo se siente contenta y satisfecha para invertir en su negocio la cantidad solicitada, ya que esta temporada de venta es buena por las clausuras en las escuelas, tiene pedidos de varios clientes ya solo para comprar la mercancía y repartirla. Tiene 38 años, estudió hasta el 6to año de primaria es casada y tiene 6 hijos, es originaria de la Mesa de Chosto. Quiere este crédito para comprar ropa satisfaciendo los pedidos de sus clientes. También espera emprender otro tipo de negocio, los fines de semana vende tostadas en el municipio de Acambay, le agradaría tener un establecimiento para vender comida típica. Tiene como proyecto a mediano plazo contar con un local para exhibir la ropa, desde que inicio con su negocio ha caminado casa por casa para colocar sus prendas, sufriendo las inclemencias del clima. 
Los otros integrantes son:
NOMBRE	        ACTIVIDAD
ROSALBA M.R.	        COMIDA
ALICIA M. A.	        ABARROTES
MA DE LOS ANGELES M.A.	ARTESANIAS
NOEMI O.T.	        DULCES
AVELINO M. A.	        COMIDA
ROSALVA M.L.          	JUGUETES
AGUSTINA L.M.	        GLOBOS
HILDA A.S.      	ROPA
ALMA ALEJANDRA M.M.	ZAPATOS X CATALOGO
texts.en:
This group, called La Presa de Chosto (The Chosto Dam), is located in the State of México. This community was known for its dam (20 years ago). The group is comprised of 10 members. María de los Ángeles M. is the president of the group. She is 39 years old, has a sixth-grade education, is married, and has a child. She sells embroidery, and has done this for six years. She is seeking a loan to purchase threads, napkins, tablecloths, etc. Julia L. has worked selling clothing for 12 years. She is seeking a loan to buy pants, shirts, and sweaters for women and men. She has around 100 clients in the areas of Chost, La Mesa, and Lanzados; little by little she has become known in the region. Initially she had a sewing workshop (15 years ago) in which she produced clothing. For personal reasons, she closed the business and distributed the capital among her associates, and from there came the idea to sell clothing. While asking for this loan, she is happy and satisfied to invest the credit into her business, as this season is good for sales due to school closures. She has orders from various clients and has to buy the clothing and distribute it. She is 38 years old, has a sixth-grade education, and is married with six children. She is originally from Mesa de Chosto. She wants this loan so she buy clothing to fill the orders of her clients. She also hopes to start another type of business. On weekends, she sells tostadas in the municipality of Acambay, and she would like to have an establishment for selling traditional foods. As a medium-term project, she has a place to display the clothing, since she has been walking house to house selling her clothes, suffering from inclement weather. The other members are: NAME: ACTIVITY ROSALBA M.R.: Food ALICIA M. A.: Groceries MA DE LOS ANGELES M.A.: Handicrafts NOEMI O.T.: Sweets AVELINO M. A.: Food ROSALVA M.L.: Toys AGUSTINA L.M. : Balloons HILDA A.S.: Clothing ALMA ALEJANDRA M.M.: Catalog shoes

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase threads, napkins, tablecloths

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina started her house-cleaning business four years ago in her hometown in Massachusetts, supporting her family who live both in the United States and in Brazil. Gina has no employees and her husband and son both work at different companies. Four years ago Gina started her house-cleaning business because she saw that the cleaning business was strong in the U.S. She saw the opportunity to grow in this area by starting a business in her hometown. Now, she hopes to gain more clients by using her first ACCION USA loan to advertise her business. She plans to make her services more visible in the surrounding area because there is a large population she has not yet targeted. Gina loves being her own boss and having that personal contact with her clients. Her greatest challenge was having the courage to start her own business. Now, she is confident enough in her service and day-to-day operations that she wants to further grow her clientele. About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA: Have you ever thought about how the cute new café on your corner or the salon you frequent every month got the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated ten million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis”. Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education. Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To advertise her house-cleaning business in the community

loans.name: Refugio's Group

texts.en: Virginia R. is from the village of Upper Bandera. She is 45 years old. Virginia is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is R.'s Group. Virginia is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Virginia has been engaged in her business for more than 26 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Virginia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used for house repair. This will be the second loan taken out by Virginia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house repair

loans.name: Mabira Womens Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
50-year-old N. Hawa’s strong-hearted enterprise has been her springboard to the modest success she has been enjoying for the last fifteen years, plying her banana-selling business. In a month, she makes 160,000 shillings. Prior to this she was a farmer. She is a widow with six children.

In this kind of business where one has many competitors, treating customers with good grace is a virtue. One’s odds of success are increased when one strikes that nice impression with clients. This, in most cases, materializes into good rapport. This is exactly what Hawa can relate to as she has created for herself a dependable niche with this way of doing things.

Hawa began this business in Najjembe, Lugazi, with a loan from the then “Feed the Children, Uganda” and is now with Pearl Microfinance. With this loan, she wants to buy more bananas to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For vehicle maintenance and repair.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana A. sells gari (a couscous-like grain made from grated cassava), maize and okro (okra) at Elmina. She is married to a cleaner and has one child. She is responsible by supporting her husband in providing the basic needs of the family. Nana has received senior high education.

Nana’s loan will be used to buy more bags of gari to sell to her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to plow back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of gari to sell to her customers

loans.name: Darling

texts.es: La joven Darling U. es originaria del municipio de Santa Rosa del Peñón, actualmente se desempeña como asistente del Alcalde de dicho municipio donde tiene tres años de laborar. Es el primer crédito que solicita en Ceprodel para la compra de una refrigeradora para tener mejores condiciones de vida en su hogar.
texts.en: Darling is from the Santa Rosa del Peñón municipality and has been working as an assistant to the mayor for three years. This is the first loan she has requested with Ceprodel and will be used to purchase a refrigerator in order to have better living conditions in her home.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Clorinda

texts.es:
Clorinda tiene 51 años D. edad, es casada y vive junto a su esposo y a su ultima hija en un caserío del distrito agrícola D. TambogranD., una zona que se encuentra ubicada en la provincia D. Piura, en la región del mismo nombre, a mas D. tres horas y media D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo, capital D. la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a la crianza y venta D. ganado ovino. Ella cría estos animales en su domicilio alimentándolos D. pastos naturales y cuando estos ya han alcanzado un buen nivel D. desarrollo los ofrece en venta a los negociantes que suelen visitar la zona en donD. vive. Con los ingresos que le brinda este negocio ella ayuda a su esposo, que es agricultor, con el sostenimiento D. la economía D. su familia.

Clorinda desea ampliar sus corrales y adquirir alimento D. modo que sus ovejas puedan desarrollarse en mejores condiciones. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 1500 nuevos soles con los cuales desea lograr su objetivo.

Ella es una mujer bastante responsable y entregada a su familia. Las personas que le conocen le consideran alguien tranquila y D. confianza.
texts.en:
Clorinda, 51, is married and lives with her husband and youngest daughter in a hamlet in the agricultural district of TambogranD., an area located in the province and region of Piura, more than three and a half hours from the city of Chiclayo, capital of the Lambayeque region. 

She earns a living raising and selling sheep. She raises these animals at home, feeding them with natural grasses. Once they have reached a good level of development she offers them for sale to the merchants who often visit the area where she lives. With the income this business brings her she helps her husband, who is a farmer, with maintaining the household economy. 

Clorinda wishes to expand her pens and purchase fodder so that her sheep may develop in better conditions. Thus she felt it was a good idea to seek for the first time a loan of 1500 soles from Edpyme Alternativa with which she hopes to achieve her goal. 

She is a highly responsible woman and dedicated to her family. Those who know her consider her to be someone level-headed and trustworthy.

loans.use: To cover expenses for improvements in the housing and fodder of sheep for sale

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has no electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She operates a cereal-selling business.  She has also sold dumplings for more than six years. Jackline faces a major challenge of seasonality for the products she sells. In the future, she hopes to own a cereals shop.    


With the loan of KSh 40,000, she is seeking to purchase iron sheets to renovate her house. She decided to join Yehu for assistance with expenses related to food and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase iron sheets to renovate her house.

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es:
En el cantón 24 De Mayo de la  provincia de Manabí, conocido por sus paisajes hermosos, por sus bosques, variedad de fauna y por su gente trabajadora dedicada a la agricultura y cría de animales. Aquí se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor.
 
Aquí encontramos a la señora María, ella tiene 47 años de edad y es madre soltera de un hijo que en la actualidad tiene 17 años de edad, el mismo que cursa el último año del colegio, nuestra socia dice que su vida fue muy difícil pero que después fue mejorando, con unos recursos que ella tenía decidió poner una tienda.
 
Ella tiene una tienda de víveres de primera necesidad como: arroz, azúcar, aceite, etc. Aunque también vende artículos de bazar y otros para el hogar como platos, ollas, planchas, y más artículos, trabaja todos los días desde las 6am hasta las 19h00 y su hijo  le ayuda en su negocio, sus productos los compra la mayoría en Portoviejo y una parte la recibe en su local. Lleva en su negocio ya muchos años y le ha ido bien.
 
Este crédito es para comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, atún y otros artículos. Está en el Banco Comunal hace ya cuatro años y le gusta porque le han ayudado mucho en momentos difíciles. Su sueño es tener una tienda más grande.
texts.en:
The 24 de Mayo canton is in the Manabí province.  It is known for its beautiful scenery, its forests, a variety of fauna, and its hard-working people who devote themselves to agriculture and raising animals.  This is where the “Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor” (Mother For a Better Future) meets every two weeks.

This is where we find María.  She is a 47 years old single mother, and she has a 17 year old child who is in his last year of school.  She says that her life has been very difficult, but it has been getting better.  She decided to use some resources that she had to set up a store.
